content.body: TabAtkins: are there things like that in JS?
Not in real JS, no.
It's something magical that only pops out of IDL.
(And which imo should be avoided as much as possible in favor of constructible things.)
oh what the crap is this
http://axis.yahoo.com/
—Hah! Wrong window. Hi.
Question stands.
TabAtkins: IDL sucks then. It must be terminated.
abarth: the allowseamless stuff should probably include some advice about how to prevent being embedded by the wrong third party
crockford left Yahoo?
ah, paypal
yeah - http://techcrunch.com/2012/05/13/paypal-gets-its-own-share-of-the-yahoo-diaspora-hires-java-icon-douglas-crockford/
ironic since the recently deposed Yahoo CEO came from paypal
the one that lied on his resume
about having a CS degree
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2012/05/13/CMKC1OHF1B.DTL - scroll down to "Resume irregularity"
love this part: "Thompson sent employees a memo apologizing for the impact that the disclosure of his true credentials had on Yahoo, without apologizing for the error itself."
apologizing for how it looked, rather than apologizing for lying.
o_O
ideas for http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Howto_spec
merge Content and Patterns
add more patterns: callbacks, class=domintro, cancelable events
It is very about:blank. You are likely to be eaten by a load.
jgraham: I don't get it :(
annevk: Oh don't mind me, I'm just experiencing the joy of about:blank today
My comment was apropos nothing else in particular
(I think I was thinking of "blank" as an alternative to "dark")
man
about:blank sure causes a lot of pain
with that in mind
hsivonen: yt?
so WebKit's location.origin is still not defined...
meh
was it ever officially proposed?
if not, I can complain to the person who added it to the code
pretty sure abarth proposed it
the way to clean this up is probably by defining the URL specification properly and then have Location and HTMLAnchorElement use it
I think [tm] already did some work in that direction
is there anything about it currently that would prevent it from being used as a supplemental interface for Location and HTMLAnchorElement?
jgraham: ?
othermaciej: yeah, the attributes are defined directly on the URL interface
othermaciej: we should probably have a [NoInterfaceObject] interface URLAttributes thingie
annevk: would that make a difference to the ability of Location to reuse it? (I might not sufficiently understand the Web IDL issues)
hsivonen: So, I am looking at about:blank. Please feel sorry for me :) Also gecko seems to have some odd behaviour if you create an iframe, insert it, and then set the src
Let me put a TC somewhere
in fact I am still super confused about the difference between sequence<Foo> and Foo[] and why both exist
othermaciej: interface URL has a bunch of other stuff (such as a constructor) that would not make sense elsewhere
actually, maybe it's just that constructor...
see http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/url/raw-file/tip/Overview.html#url
jgraham: Please don't try to make Opera behave like current Gecko behaves
jgraham: unfortunately, I've been blocked from making progress on changing Gecko yet again
jgraham: but the plan still is to change it
hsivonen: I'm not trying to :)
I'm trying to understand what behaviour is actually web compatible
webben: The deps of http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=923 now track Maven stuff
(the spec is not)
webben: I have almost no clue about Maven and depend on people who want Maven support to contribute pom.xml patches
I am told that it is relatively easy to change Opera to make it Webkit-like
jgraham: firing onload synchronously?
events that fire sync with parse are evil
I still want to make the events for about:blank to fire async
Why?
jgraham: they can run scripts, so they require putting Gecko in a state where it's safe to run scripts
which add both code and perf overhead
also interesting document.write() call opportunities
http://hoppipolla.co.uk/tests/about_blank/002.html
In Opera that currently claims to be 2 async events, but apparently it is sure that the events will run before any other script
In webkit it is one sync/one async
In gecko there is only one event
annevk: I just read the spec and complained about the parameter stuff
annevk: anyway - are constructors inherited? I think they are not, so it doesn't matter
annevk: only issue would be whether prototype-hacking the URL interface object would affect HTMLAnchorElement
othermaciej: what you want is implementing them and defining them in a single place, but the effect should be that they appear to be on HTMLAnchorElement, Location, and URL independently I think
I don't really care how we go about that, I guess heycam|away can figure that out :)
hsivonen: So, what behaviour are you proposing, and how sure are you that it's web compatible?
it might be that "implements" does exactly that, but I don't know what happens to Constructors
That's 'implements', AIUI
annevk: I think it might just work for Location and HTMLAnchorElement to both inherit from URL
No
There is no multiple inheritance in IDL
ok, whatever the alternative to multiple inheritance is to add a mixin (is there such a thing?)
implements copies "constants, attributes or operations"
So, implements should be fine
Location could just inherit, since it has no base class
I think HTMLAnchorElement could use "implements"
It would be silly to make them different, IMO
Location could use "implements" too despite not having any other base class
I do not know if there is any other comparable case in the HTML DOM
where an element and a non-element share an interface in common
HTMLElement and Document for a few members
but they're just duplicates
duplicated*
othermaciej: hi, what's the status on the <hgroup> issue?
Stevef: I do not know offhand
do you remember the issue number?
there were draft reviews of all the proposals in progress, I do not recall if they have been posted yet
if not, that is the next step
othermaciej: http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/164
othermaciej: haven't been posted yet, paulc soad he was going to post them about 2 weeks ago
ok, I'll check in with him
othermaciej: thanks
can anybody tell me what ted oconnors nick is?
hober,
Ms2ger:thanks
Np
hober: any response to this http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2012May/0008.html ?
hsivonen: I'm looking into the Maven issue btw. How do you build and test htmlparser yourself? I want to verify my pom.xml doesn't break your workflow?
webben: I use a plain Eclipse project setup with its intregated incremental builder
webben: pom.xml isn't part of my workflow at all except for making release bundles for the Maven Central Repository
webben: hence, I don't grok pom.xml
http://forums.whatwg.org/bb3/viewtopic.php?f=10&t=5000#p7899 anyone have suggestions about what to do about this?
MathML in Opera Next gets better and better, I have to say
ashemedai: Interesting. Examples of things that improved?
jgraham: http://www.in-nomine.org/~asmodai/3d.html
jgraham: scroll to alpha blending
The entire layout of that part is just tight now, as it should
of course, the other ones still can use some work :)
Heh, that looks bad on my opera-next
Yeah, maybe I am missing some fonts
But I see [r] instead of [r,g,b]
Fortunately, Gecko is there when you need a good MathML implementation ;)
oh wait
Good point jgraham
Totally missed that
Ms2ger: And you are right, just still have this pipedream of seeing Chrome and Opera implement more of MathML
publish more mathml content so it becomes a sitecompat issue :-)
Acid4 ;)
Convince Google to make google.com depend on MathML :p
ashemedai: I'm afraid that as long as we use CSS and CSS cannot describe all of MathML displaying Math in Opera will be bad :(
Ms2ger: Well given acid 3 that would probably give you stubs for MathML
Acid4: The entire MathML test suite? :)
mmm, opera next updater gives me a cannot validate file when it tries to grab the update file, at least manual update worked
each pixel is a test
annevk: Yea, but I'm happy with the intermediate work already
zcorpan, ... and they animate ;)
annevk: I should just use Mathjax in the meantime
ashemedai: nah, please publish MathML
Does annevankesteren.nl have any?
ashemedai: and write about the problems you encounter
annevk: I'll be adding more formulae to that page in the weekend.
Ms2ger: I suck at math
annevk: as in blog?
ashemedai: for instance
Can do that :)
you can also create a wiki page on the WHATWG wiki
we try to track/document shortcomings of all web technology
so whenever someone gets a chance to improve it, they know where to start
annevk, I'm sorry to hear that :)
Ms2ger: the people who wanted me to define matrix-aware layout APIs were too
Meh, that's not real math
annevk: Ah, sure, I can do the MathML page on Whatwg wiki
So who do I bother for an account? :P
ashemedai: you message me an email address
ashemedai: oh and give me a desired username
Thanks!
annevk: Is there a specific subsection where status/shortcomings are discussed?
Where I hook a new page under
[[Category:Proposals]] maybe
hmm
[[Category:ToBeAssimilated]]
oh or maybe http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Category:Spec_coordination
Ms2ger: :P
Spec coordination is probably good
annevk: ok, done. Got the page up, linked under Spec coordination
"Spec coordination is what keeps #whatwg busy at night."
heh
oh I wrote that
lol
Well at least you can laugh at yourself
ashemedai: convince Wikipedia to go all-in with MathML without MathJax fallbacks
yeah Wikipedia really ought to switch
hsivonen: I can try asking some of my Wikipedia-Unicode contacts about that
Think that would be incentive for the browser makers to step up the game?
ashemedai: If Wikipedia went all-in with Presentation MathML, yeah.
ashemedai: (if they did Content MathML, they'd be too far out there)
is it even agreed we should keep Content MathML?
annevk: no
annevk: we decided to make Gecko not corrupt Content MathML alternatives in clipboard operations, though
mkay
annevk: so we're trying to be nice about it
I guess the MathML wiki page should at some point define the subset we're interested in
annevk: but no plans to really support it, AFAIK
if the Math WG is not going to do that
annevk: are there parts of Presentation MathML that we're *not* interested in?
annevk: I thought the subset was "Presentation MathML"
what is <annotation-xml> part of?
lala land?
We've pretty much said we're only really interested in http://www.w3.org/TR/mathml-for-css/
annevk: it's an integration point on the edge of Presentation MathML

hsivonen: So re: about:blank it seems like we will go for something WebKit-like unless we are persuaded otherwise (e.g. by a gecko implementation that is web compatible and doesn't have synchronous events or task queue mangling)
annevk: you walk off the cliff when you walk into that subtree
Or by finding out that "webkit like" is actually hard to implement in detail
hsivonen: right so maybe that should be "disallowed"
i.e., only really interested in the subset of MathML that can be described by CSS.
jgraham: :-(
Of course as CSS grows that may expand.
annevk: depends on how you view use cases for alternative semantic content for copying and pasting into symbolic algebra software
hsivonen: Yeah, sorry :( But it is hard to argue against something that I'm told is - at a high level - simple in our implementation and has known web compat properties
jgraham: I understand
jgraham: I fail for what I want being continuously vaporware
So feel free to let me know what you think such a page on MathML needs - http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/MathML
I'll add some implementation notes/details as soon as I get home
ashemedai: feel free to phrase it more direct
annevk: Phrase what more direct?
ashemedai: like "Content MathML should not be used and is not going to be implemented by browsers."
though maybe mention the copy-and-paste exception hsivonen was talking about
Ah
if we communicate our intentions clearly, there's less room for surprise
Gotcha
(and more room for debate, people might disagree with our stance)
is making modest progress with http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Howto_spec
defined a bunch of event patterns
and callbacks

http://lachy.id.au/dev/markup/tests/html5/charref/ lists 1449 named character references, while http://whatwg.org/html/named-character-references.html lists 2232
would there be any interest in an updated test case for this?
i was thinking of making one that automates the testing through JS
matjas: That test case has 1449ish lines, but lists multiple named character references on a single line
<tr><td>&<td>& &amp &<td>U+00026 AMPERSAND
etc
right
which might make up some of the difference
(or all of it)
not all of it; there are only 3581 occurences of & in the source
anyhow, just wanted to know if it hasn’t been done already, or if lachlan had an update planned
Hmm, looks like it excludes at least the multi-codepoint references (∾̳ etc)
zcorpan: without checking the spec i’d guess A
matjas: http://i.imgur.com/Emi0l.gif

There's http://code.google.com/p/html5lib/source/browse/testdata/tokenizer/namedEntities.test which would hopefully be up to date, but I don't know whether there's a way to run those tests inside a browser (rather than a standalone parser)
C
Philip`: okay, I’ll just give it a whirl then — can’t hurt, right?
Ms2ger: http://i.imgur.com/Emi0l.gif
Nice
matjas: More tests never hurt :-)
http://test.w3.org/html/tests/submission/Opera/html5lib/tests/test_tokenizer_namedEntities.html perhaps?
jgraham: woah @ source
You can't decode uri components in your head?

Ms2ger: Seems test-runner doesn't run in IE10? I just wanted to check something, but seems it never really starts :-)  Is it known, or an authoring fault from my side on making the testrunner.htm file?
matjas: It was supposed to be a very general purpose way of converting the html5lib tests that didn't optimise for readability
Ms2ger: fsck, it was (my :P) authoring error as I had a hunch it might be.
odinho, does it work in IE10, then? I never tried :)
Ms2ger: Well, I'll see shortly, I need to stop reading IRC backlog first :P I'm easily distracted it seems.
Ms2ger: Aaaand, it works! :-)

Hixie: why does whatwg.org/html/named-character-references.html#entity-DotDot have \u25CC\u20DC in the glyph cell rather than just \u20DC?
file a bug
e
matjas: I expect it's a placeholder so that the combining character is sensibly visible
zcorpan: it doesn’t seem like a bug/typo, as other cells have it too… i just don’t see why — it doesn’t make it clearer
Philip`: i think the extra circle just makes it harder to see the combining char
guess it’s just me then
If you didn't have any character in front of it then it'd appear too far to the left, which would also look unclear
http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/25cc/index.htm has a comment relating to combining character indications
(I presume that comment is originally from the Unicode standard itself)
other mismatches between code points + glyphs on that page: https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=17170#c1
^ writing those tests pays off already :)
test results: WebKit currently fails on 1 named character reference (&AElig doesn’t match Æ), the WebKit in latest stable Safari has 94 errors, Presto and Gecko pass all tests
matjas: Nice, but you should test one of the many parts of the spec that *doesn't* already have tests. Then you should submit the tests to the W3C :)
matjas, or review the submitted tests, if you like that :)
s/that/torture/
shh
Uh right
Testcase review is really fun!
You should do it!
Hah
thanks, i’d rather write my own :')
Problem is, if people start reviewing TCs, they will quit before they get to writing them
And I would rather have people writing TCs
Even though that means more reviewing...
Funny, Firefox does 1 test better than IE10 in MS' idb testsuite. But they both fail the same number (the diff is not-run).
But both more or less lies at 84% pass.
wonders when WebKit will start updating their idb implementation...
matjas: the ⟨ thing is a problem in the publishing pipeline
matjas: there's a bug on it somewhere, we haven't quite located the source
annevk: hmm, can’t you just use numeric character references instead of the raw characters, or are those unreliable as well?
matjas: you mean instead of named entities?
no, i mean for the “glyph” cell

is debating whether to join the HTMLWG telcon this morning.

tantek: lol
tantek: yes, but only if you do it ironically
tantek: I can tell you how it goes: http://annevankesteren.nl/2010/12/html-wg-teleconference
tantek: maybe you can write down your experience as well so we can compare notes and see how things have progressed
ok, I leave it to #whatwg - please express +1/-1/0
+1 (plus notes)
+1 if you write it down
otherwise waste of time
annevk - your post is similar to most of my past experiences on the telcon
however, when I've had an issue (as in an Issue in tracker) to discuss, and have specifically brought up questions, typically I've had very productive discussions with the chairs.

so I think the telcons are mostly what you make of them. if just lurking, it's perhaps not that useful. if you have specific business to raise/discuss with the chairs, it can be useful. and anyone can do that during the "any other business" part of the telcon.
not sure why you'd dial in for that, but then I'm not sure why I ever dialed into teleconferences anyway

annevk - mostly I've dialed in to help move along the various <time> and <data> element change proposals that I made to officially make the changes happen that I discussed/debated/designed with Hixie (and somewhat in this channel) ages ago - after we got rough consensus at the TPAC HTMLWG f2f last year.
the <time> stuff was handled in such a fucked up way
W3C HTML was not updated for months
Mm, we support rest parameters now

annevk - W3C HTML5 still lacks <data> :(
function foo(...rest) {}

I'd be glad to see Content MathML dropped, since it contains the only two tagname conflicts in the language.  Presentation MathML was careful (or lucky?) not to collide with SVG or HTML in any way.

in custom elements spec, I am very tempted to be just describe how things happen from JS perspective (i.e. prototype chain, objects in it, etc.). However, WebIDL/DOM4 and most other specs tend to specify things in terms of interfaces and generic inheritance concepts. Should do the former and not worry about consistency with existing specs, or should I do the latter and try to fit the concept of cu
stomizable DOM interfaces into the WebIDL world?
Sounds like you're doing something wrong
Ms2ger: yes, but what? :)
Well, I don't know what you're trying to accomplish
trying to capture http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/webcomponents/raw-file/tip/explainer/index.html#custom-element-section as a spec.
specifically, describing the process of building a custom DOM element with a prototype chain, which includes a DOM object and an arbitrary JS object.
I don't think I want to lat you do that, dave
Ms2ger: it's too late for that, R2D2
actually, http://www.w3.org/TR/WebIDL/#dfn-interface I think is workable
it's just such a weird transpiler operation, having to speak in WebIDL when really everyone knows it's JS.
can we just rewrite all specs to be in JS? :)
It isn't
It's C++
Ms2ger: that's just an implementation detail. C++ tries darn well to pretend it's not there. And Microsoft peeps are leading the charge to make it even less visible.
in IE10 that is
dglazkov: is there agreement that we want to do such a thing?
Ms2ger: stumbled upon http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/spec-prod/2012AprJun/0075.html
Heh

Is it an accessibility concern?
yes

(that bug is invalid)
AryehGregor: yt?
"Ecma International now hosts a normative HTML copy of Ecma-262, Edition 5.1  The ECMAScript Language Specification."
It's not actually normative
tries to read over the recent posts here but gets a headache and decides to not bother.
I'd also love to see the day where things didn't seem to get so overcomplicated with everything. Lol.
hey - is anyone around who can clarify something for me in the DOM4 spec?
specifically what looks like a spec bug in the section about DOMException
Just ask.
well the problem I have is that there's no specifically called-out field for the string-based exception type in DOMException
so if a caller wants to check the exception type using the newer string-based mechanism, there's no way to do it
i.e. rather than if (ex.code == DOMException.IndexSizeError) ….,
there's no equivalent for the string "IndexSizeError"
ie.
if (ex.<???> == "IndexSizeError") {…}
ex.name? (consistent with DOMError) or ex.type (alluded to in the spec but not called out in the IDL)
alecflett, it's .name
alecflett, it's in Web IDL that it's defined that exception objects get a name property
ahh.. .thanks for the clarification
might be nice to have some non-normative reference to that somewhere in the DOM4 spec as I spent a good deal of time looking for it!
